Chapter 21, Continuation of the Section on Conditions, Part 2: What is meant by name-and-form as a condition for contact?
It is said that the eye and form as conditions give rise to eye-consciousness. Due to the combination of the three, contact arises.
Herein, the eye and form are called form;
The feeling, perception, volition, and consciousness that arise from them are called name.
Thus, name-and-form as a condition gives rise to eye-contact. This is called name-and-form as a condition for contact.
Up to the mind and mental objects as conditions give rise to mind-consciousness. Due to the combination of the three, contact arises.
Herein, the form cognized by all mind-consciousnesses is called form;
The feeling, perception, volition, and consciousness that arise from them are called name.
Thus, name-and-form as a condition gives rise to mind-contact. This is called name-and-form as a condition for contact.
Furthermore, in the SÅ«tra of Teaching Pulagu, the Buddha said:
Pulagu!

What is this consciousness?
It refers to gandharva.
... it combines with the body of the kalala.
This combination with the body of the kalala is called form;
the feeling, perception, volitional formations, and consciousness produced from that are called name.
At that time, name-and-form arising together with improper attention as a condition, various contacts arise in the mother's womb. This is called name-and-form as a condition for contact.

The embryo that is relied upon is called form;
the feeling, perception, volitional formations, and consciousness produced from that are called name.
At that time, name-and-form arising together with improper attention as a condition, various contacts arise in the mother's womb. This is called name-and-form as a condition for the six sense bases.
There is another type of person who, due to being bound by the entanglements of greed, hatred, and delusion, creates the three kinds of evil bodily, verbal, and mental actions.
Among them, the evil bodily and verbal actions are called form;
the evil mental actions are called name.

Due to these evil actions, which are the conditions for name and form, when the body perishes and life ends, one falls into hell and various sensations arise. This is called name and form as a condition for contact.
As explained for hell, so should it be understood for animals and hungry ghosts.
There is another type of person who, with regard to the pleasures of the human realm, fixes their mind in longing for them. Because of this longing,
they create the three kinds of good bodily, verbal, and mental actions that can lead to rebirth in the human realm.
Among them, the good bodily and verbal actions are called form;
the good mental actions are called name.

Due to these good actions, which are the conditions for name and form, when the body perishes and life ends, one is reborn in the human realm and various sensations arise. This is called name and form as a condition for contact.
As explained for the human realm, so should it be understood for the Heaven of the Four Kings, up to the Heaven of Free Enjoyment of Manifestations by Others.

There is another type who fixates their mind on the BrahmakÄyika gods and aspires to be born there. Because of this aspiration, they diligently cultivate practices, free from desire and evil unwholesome states, and abide in the first meditative absorption.
In this meditative absorption, the bodily precepts, verbal precepts, and pure livelihood are called form;
the feelings, perceptions, volitions, and consciousness arising from them are called name.
Based on this as a condition, when the body perishes and life ends, the various contacts that arise in the continuity of the BrahmakÄyika gods are called contact with name-and-form as its condition.
As explained for the BrahmakÄyika gods, the Brahmapurohita gods up to the neither-perception-nor-non-perception gods should be understood in the same way, according to their respective cases.
Furthermore, in the MahÄnidÄna SÅ«tra, the Venerable Ä€nanda asked the Buddha:

No, World-Honored One.
World-Honored One!

if this characteristic does not exist, can one still designate contact that is resistance?

World-Honored One!

World-Honored One!
Therefore, Ä€nanda!
All kinds of contact have name-and-form as their condition. This is called name-and-form as a condition for contact.

In this way, the various kinds of contact arise, originate, come to be, and appear due to name-and-form as their condition, name-and-form as their support, and name-and-form as their basis. Therefore, it is called name-and-form as a condition for contact.
How is it that the six sense bases have contact as a condition?

It means that the eye and form as conditions give rise to eye consciousness, and the coming together of the three gives rise to contact. Up to the mind and mental objects as conditions give rise to mind consciousness, and the coming together of the three gives rise to contact. This is called contact with the six sense bases as its condition.
Furthermore, the eye and form as conditions give rise to eye consciousness, and the coming together of the three gives rise to contact.
Herein, the eye as an internal condition and form as an external condition give rise to eye contact.

Up to the mind and mental objects as conditions give rise to mind consciousness, and the coming together of the three gives rise to contact. Herein, the mind as an internal condition and mental objects as an external condition give rise to mind contact.
This is called contact with the six sense bases as its condition.
Furthermore, the eye and form as conditions give rise to eye consciousness, and the coming together of the three gives rise to contact.

Herein, eye contact has the eye, form, and eye consciousness as its conditions. Up to the mind and mental objects as conditions give rise to mind consciousness, and the coming together of the three gives rise to contact.
Herein, mind contact has the mind, mental objects, and mind consciousness as its conditions. This is called contact with the six sense bases as its condition.
Furthermore, the eye and form as conditions give rise to eye-consciousness. Due to the combination of the three, contact arises.
In this case, the eye, form, and eye-consciousness are not contact, but contact arises due to the combination of the three.
Up to the mind and dharmas as conditions give rise to mental consciousness. Due to the combination of the three, contact arises.
In this case, the mind, dharmas, and mental consciousness are not contact, but contact arises due to the combination of the three.
This is called the six sense bases as a condition for contact.

In this way, all contacts arise with the six sense bases as a condition, with the six sense bases as a support, with the six sense bases as a foundation, and thus arise, are born, and appear collectively, and are therefore called the six sense bases as a condition for contact.
How is contact a condition for feeling?
It is like this: the eye and form as conditions give rise to eye-consciousness. Due to the combination of the three, contact arises. Contact as a condition gives rise to feeling.
Up to the mind and dharmas as conditions give rise to mental consciousness. Due to the combination of the three, contact arises. Due to contact as a condition, feeling arises.
This is called contact as a condition for feeling.

Furthermore, eye and form as conditions give rise to eye consciousness, and the combination of the three gives rise to contact, which may accord with pleasant feeling, or with painful feeling, or with neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant feeling. Contact that accords with pleasant feeling, as a condition, gives rise to pleasant feeling. Contact that accords with painful feeling, as a condition, gives rise to painful feeling. Contact that accords with neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant feeling, as a condition, gives rise to neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant feeling.

Up to: mind and mental objects as conditions give rise to mind consciousness, and the combination of the three gives rise to contact, which may accord with pleasant feeling, or with painful feeling, or with neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant feeling. Contact that accords with pleasant feeling, as a condition, gives rise to pleasant feeling. Contact that accords with painful feeling, as a condition, gives rise to painful feeling. Contact that accords with neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant feeling, as a condition, gives rise to neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant feeling. This is called feeling with contact as its condition.
Furthermore, as a scripture says, the Venerable Ä€nanda said to the elder Gautama:

The eye element, form element, and eye-consciousness element have their own distinct natures. The two that accord with pleasant feeling serve as conditions to give rise to eye-consciousness. Because of the combination of the three, contact arises, called contact that accords with pleasant feeling. This contact that accords with pleasant feeling serves as a condition to give rise to pleasant feeling.

The two that accord with painful feeling serve as conditions to give rise to eye-consciousness. Because of the combination of the three, contact arises, called contact that accords with painful feeling. This contact that accords with painful feeling serves as a condition to give rise to painful feeling.

The two that accord with neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling serve as conditions to give rise to eye-consciousness. Because of the combination of the three, contact arises, called contact that accords with neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling. This contact that accords with neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling serves as a condition to give rise to neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling.
The remaining five elements are explained in the same way. This is called feeling with contact as its condition.
Next, in the MahÄnidÄna SÅ«tra, Venerable Ä€nanda asked the Buddha:

Extensively speaking up to if there is no eye contact, can there be internal pleasant, painful, or neither-pleasant-nor-painful feeling arising with eye contact as a condition?
No, World-Honored One.
Up to if there is no mind contact, can there be internal pleasant, painful, or neither-pleasant-nor-painful feeling arising with mind contact as a condition?

No, World-Honored One.

In this way, all feelings arise with contact as a condition, with contact as a support, with contact as a basis, and thus arise, equally arise, are born, equally born, accumulate, and appear, and are therefore called contact as a condition for feeling.
What is feeling as a condition for craving?

That is to say, eye and form as conditions give rise to eye consciousness, and the coming together of the three gives rise to contact. Contact as a condition gives rise to feeling, and feeling as a condition gives rise to craving.

Up to: mind and mental objects as conditions give rise to mind consciousness, and the coming together of the three gives rise to contact. Contact as a condition gives rise to feeling, and feeling as a condition gives rise to craving.
This is called feeling as a condition for craving.
Furthermore, because of the feeling of the flavor of the eye as a condition, one repeatedly dwells in accordance with the eye.
Because of dwelling in accordance with it, one repeatedly gives rise to craving and attachment to the eye, grasping it, guarding it, and strongly attached to it with defilement and love.

World-Honored One!ğŸ”½Herein, bhikkhus, with ignorance as condition, volitional formations [come to be]; with volitional formations as condition, consciousness; with consciousness as condition, name-and-form; with name-and-form as condition, the six sense bases; with the six sense bases as condition, contact; with contact as condition, feeling; with feeling as condition, craving; with craving as condition, clinging; with clinging as condition, existence; with existence as condition, birth; with birth as condition, aging-and-death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, displeasure, and despair come to be. Therefore, all seeking is conditioned by craving, with craving as its source, with craving as its origin, and with craving as its cause.

In this way, all craving arises, is produced, accumulates, and appears due to feeling as its condition, feeling as its support, and feeling as its establishment. Therefore, it is called 'craving conditioned by feeling.'
How is it that craving conditions grasping?
That which is first born is called craving.
When craving increases and becomes strong, it is called grasping.
What is this again?
It is like when someone fixes their mind on observing the objects of desire and gives rise to the fetters of desire and greed.
From this entanglement, they give rise to other entanglements, which become increasingly intense, more intense, and more complete.
The previously arisen entanglements are called craving;
The subsequently arisen entanglements are called grasping, which is called craving as a condition for grasping.
Furthermore, there is someone who, regarding form or formless objects, fixes their mind on observation, giving rise to form-realm desire or formless-realm desire.
From this entanglement, they give rise to other entanglements, which become increasingly intense, more intense, and more complete.
The previously arisen entanglements are called craving;
The subsequently arisen entanglements are called grasping, which is called craving as a condition for grasping.
Furthermore, the Buddha said in the Sutra on the Pit of Fire:

I will proclaim for you, monks, the essential teachings on the discernment of the aggregates, namely the four establishments of mindfulness, the four right efforts, the four bases of supernatural power, the five faculties, the five powers, the seven factors of awakening, and the eightfold noble path.

When I proclaim these essential teachings on the discernment of the aggregates, there are some foolish ones who do not dwell in sharp faith, love, and respect for what I say, and they are slow to attain the unsurpassed destruction of defilements.
There are also some wise ones who are able to dwell in sharp faith, love, and respect for what I say, and they quickly attain the unsurpassed destruction of defilements.

There is also a type who, regarding the teachings on the form aggregate, contemplates the self as following along with it, wondering what conditions this contemplation, what accumulates it, what kind it is, and what it arises from.

Namely, the various feelings produced by the contact of ignorance give rise to craving as a condition. The formations produced by this [craving] take that as a condition, use that as their origination, are of the same kind as that, and arise from that.
What does this [craving] that gives rise to craving take as a condition, use as its origination, is of the same kind as what, and arises from what?

Namely, the various feelings produced by the contact of ignorance give rise to craving as a condition. The craving produced by this [feeling] takes feeling as a condition, uses feeling as its origination, is of the same kind as feeling, and arises from feeling.
What does this [craving] that gives rise to feeling take as a condition, use as its origination, is of the same kind as what, and arises from what?

The various feelings produced by this [contact] take contact as a condition, use contact as their origination, are of the same kind as contact, and arise from contact.
What does this [contact] that gives rise to contact take as a condition, use as its origination, is of the same kind as what, and arises from what?
Namely, the six sense bases.
The contact that arises from this has the six sense bases as its condition, the six sense bases as its origin, is the kind of the six sense bases, and arises from the six sense bases.
Thus, the six sense bases are impermanent, conditioned, created, and arise from many conditions.
Thus, contact, feeling, craving, and the observed activities are also impermanent, conditioned, created, and arise from many conditions.
Those who observe form as the self give rise to the fetters of the view of a real self.

The formations produced by this [craving] take that [ignorance] as their condition, use that [ignorance] as their accumulation, are of that kind, and arise from that [ignorance].
Expounded extensively up to this: the six sense bases are impermanent, conditioned, created, and arise from many conditions.
Thus, contact, feeling, craving, conceit, and formations are also impermanent, conditioned, created, and arise from many conditions.
Thus, this conceit is the conceit-bond arising from the view of self-existence.
From this bond, one further gives rise to other bonds, which become increasingly superior, more intense, and more complete.
The previously arisen bonds are called craving;
The subsequently arisen bonds are transformed and called grasping. This is called the condition of craving for grasping.
Furthermore, there are those who grasp that the world is permanent, impermanent, both permanent and impermanent, or neither permanent nor impermanent.
They grasp at the world as having an end, or having no end, or both having an end and having no end, or neither having an end nor having no end.
